## Last Years Finalists videos

There were [16 finalists at last years Festival of Code](https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLrlo60-9HUYnGQJSQzAueH9pe8z2DeZUS), some highlighted videos include:

* [Project Thoth](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RZLRILzVS6Q) - improving the language used on the Internet

* [YouDraw](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-8UPv7thy4o) -  make animations from YouTube videos by crowdsourcing

## Open Data 

There is only one rule for the competition element, and that is that the hacks put forward to present on stage in Birmingham, must contain at least one piece of Open Data.  

* [What is OpenData](http://festival.yrs.io/updates/what-is-open-data/)
* YRS OpenData resources page](http://festival.yrs.io/dataresources/)
* [Ordinance Survey map data](https://www.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/)
* [Map of every KFC restaurant in the UK](http://www.flyingtophat.co.uk/blog/2014/05/08/map-of-every-kfc-restaurant-in-uk.html)
* [Map of every McDonalds restaurant in the UK](http://www.flyingtophat.co.uk/blog/2011/11/14/map-of-every-mcdonalds-restaurant-in-uk.html)

You can of course use any OpenData you want to as part of your project.

## Newbies 

Young Rewired State foster a community of already-able young technical people. It is assumed that

every person who attends one of our events can write and understand some form of programming

or scripting language. However, it is completely inevitable that young people with less technical skill

will come along to the centre during the week.

As a mentor, we would also suggest that you use the following two activities to help aid less-skilled

participants in learning the basics.

> Intro to Web Development

To help newbies get started with the basics in HTML, CSS and Javascript, we have put together an

introductory exercise that can be found here:

http://www.yrs.io/get-started

The step-by-step format should allow for young people to work through the exercise without

constant supervision, giving you the freedom to move between groups.

> Ruby’s Threads

Another exercise that can help when catering for skills gaps is our community project, Ruby’s

Threads:

http://rb.yrs.io

We have put all the code in our GitHub account ready for participants to fork and play around with.

This is a great exercise to introduce even your more advanced coders to GitHub:

https://github.com/youngrewired/rubys-threads

Participants will learn:

● How to setup git on your computer

● How to change 'branches' in git

● How to make changes to the project

● How to push your changes back up to GitHub

● How to submit a pull request on GitHub

We’d love to see a Ruby designed for each Festival of Code centre. Perhaps ‘designing a centre

Ruby’ is an exercise the whole centre can get involved with on day one, allowing for easier

integration of newbies.

Once your participants have completed the above two exercises and are feeling more confident

with code, it’s time to integrate them with the rest of the group.


## Tips 
* Make sure your hack has not been done before (YRS hack pages, Google)

## Winning Categories
* Best example of code - really awesome code
* Best example of design - intuitive, beautiful, interactive & works
* Code a better country - a civic tech hack, something for the benefit of your family, friends, community or country
* Should Exist - something that everyone would use if it existed
* Best in show - all of the above
* Peoples choice award - anyone can vote
